'''Eddie "Guitar" Burns''' (February 8, 1928 – December 12, 2012)<ref name="Obit">{{cite web|url=http://www.macombdaily.com/article/20121213/ENTERTAINMENT04/121219804/-lost-legend-eddie-burns-dies-at-age-84|author=Joe Ballor|title='Lost legend' Eddie Burns dies at age 84 : Obituary|publisher=Macombdaily|accessdate=2012-12-14}}</ref> was an [[United States|American]] [[Detroit blues]] [[guitarist]], [[harmonica]] player, [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]].<ref name="AMG"/> His career spanned seven decades, and in terms of Detroit bluesmen, Burns was deemed second only in stature to [[John Lee Hooker]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Encyc">{{cite web |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3431000013.html|title=Eddie "Guitar" Burns |author=Manheim, James M. |publisher=Encyclopedia.com |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref>

==Biography==
Burns was born in [[Belzoni, Mississippi|Belzoni]], [[Mississippi]], United States.<ref name="Dead"/> His father was a [[sharecropping|sharecropper]] who performed as a singer in [[medicine show]]s, although Burns was mainly raised by his grandparents. He was self-taught in the harmonica and made his first [[guitar]].<ref name="Encyc"/>

Initially influenced by exposure to the music of [[Sonny Boy Williamson I]] and [[Big Bill Broonzy]], Burns relocated from the [[Mississippi delta]] via [[Waterloo, Iowa|Waterloo]], [[Iowa]] to [[Detroit]] in 1948.<ref name="Encyc"/> Originally Burns excelled playing the harmonica, and his debut [[single (music)|single]], "Notoriety Woman" (1948), featured this ability accompanied by the guitar playing of John T. Smith. Burns tells how he met John Lee Hooker here: "Well see, John T. and me was playing at a house party this particular Saturday night.  We was in Detroit Black Bottom...so Hooker was on his way home from somewhere - I guess he was at some other party, house parties used to be real plentiful here.  Hooker heard it, knocked at the door, and they let him in.  He introduced himself and he sat down and played some with us.  And then, he liked the way I was blowing harmonica...he had a session coming up on Tuesday, this was on a Saturday.  And so then, he wanted to know if I wanted to do this session with him on Tuesday.  And I told him, yes, naturally.  So that's how John T. and me went down to cut for Hooker.  When we got through the man wanted to know what I had.  I had one song, "Notoriety Woman." And so he said I'd need two, and I sat there and made up "Papa's Boogie."" <ref>Blue Suit Records, "Detroit" liner notes, 1989</ref> However, by the following year Burns was playing guitar accompaniment on [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] by [[John Lee Hooker]].<ref name="AMG"/> 

Billed at times as Big Daddy, Little Eddie, or Big Ed, Burns performed regularly in Detroit [[nightclub]]s, but had to supplement his earnings by working as a [[mechanic]].<ref name="Encyc"/> In those early years Burns's own recording was not prolific with just a handful of tracks released on several [[record label|labels]].  His output veered from Detroit blues to [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] as the 1960s progressed, when he issued a number of singles in that decade on [[Harvey Fuqua]]'s Harvey Records label.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p61051/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Eddie "Guitar" Burns |author=Dahl, Bill |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> Now permanently billed as Eddie "Guitar" Burns, he appeared on Hooker's album ''[[The Real Folk Blues]]'' (1966).<ref name="Encyc"/>

In 1972, Burns undertook a [[Europe]]an [[concert tour|tour]] and recorded his debut [[album]], ''Bottle Up & Go'' in [[London]], [[England]].<ref name="Encyc"/><ref name="Wirz"/> This was followed by an appearance at the [[Ann Arbor Blues and Jazz Festival]] in 1973.  Two years later Burns toured Europe again, this time as part of the billing of 'American Blues Legends', organised by Jim Simpson of [[Big Bear Records]], who was the first to insert the epithet "guitar" into his name.<ref name="Encyc"/> Burns self penned track, "Orange Driver", was recorded by [[The J. Geils Band]] (''[[Hotline (J. Geils Band album)|Hotline]]'', 1975).<ref>{{cite web|last=Sendra |first=Tim |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/hotline-mw0000317254 |title=Hotline - J. Geils Band : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2012-12-16}}</ref> In August 1976, Burns performed his song "Bottle Up & Go" live on the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[television program]], ''[[So It Goes (TV series)|So It Goes]]''.

In 1989 Burns released an album titled ''Detroit'' on Blue Suit Records, where his ability on both guitar and harmonica were displayed.<ref name="AMG"/>  In February 1992, Burns appeared alongside [[Jack Owens (blues singer)|Jack Owens]], Bud Spires, and [[Lonnie Pitchford]] at the seventh annual New York Winter Blues Festival.<ref>{{cite journal
| first= 
| last= 
| year= February 1992
| title= New York Magazine
| edition= Volume 25, No. 7
| publisher= 
| location= 
| page= 90
| id= }}</ref> By 1994, Burns had been granted the Michigan Heritage Award.<ref name="Encyc"/>

In 1998, the Detroit Blues Society presented Burns with its Lifetime Achievement Award. 

His brother, [[Jimmy Burns]], is a [[soul blues]] musician, who lives in [[Chicago]], and played guitar on Burns 2002 album ''Snake Eyes''.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Encyc"/> Burns final recorded offering was ''Second Degree Burns'', released when he was 77 years of age.<ref name="Albums"/>

In 2008, [[Little Sonny]] performed with Burns on the latter's final live performance at the Motor City Blues & Boogie Woogie Festival.<ref name="Obit"/>

Burns died of [[heart failure]] aged 84 in December 2012.<ref name="Dead">{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2012b.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 2012 July To December |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-16}}</ref>

==Discography==

===Albums===
*''Bottle Up & Go'' (1972) - Action
*''Detroit Blackbottom'' (1975) - [[Big Bear Records]]
*''Lonesome Feeling'' (1986) - (Black & Blue Records BB455.2) Recorded in The Netherlands
*''Detroit'' (1989) - Blue Suit
*''Snake Eyes'' (2002) - [[Delmark Records]]
*''Second Degree Burns'' (2005) - Blue Suit<ref name="Albums">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/eddie-guitar-burns-mn0000793459/discography |title=Eddie "Guitar" Burns | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}</ref><ref name="Wirz"/>

===Singles===
*"Notoriety Woman" (1948) - Palda Records
*"Hello Miss Jessie Lee" (1953) - DeLuxe Records
*"Biscuit Baking Mama" (1954) - [[Checker Records]]
*"Treat Me Like I Treat You" (1957) - [[Chess Records]]
*"Orange Driver" (1961) - Harvey Records
*"The Thing To Do" (1961) - Harvey Records
*"(Don't Be) Messing With My Bread" (1962) - Harvey Records
*"Wig Wearin' Woman" (1965) - Von Records
*"I Am Leaving" (1965) - Von Records
*"Don't Even Try It" (1982) - [[Red Bird Records]]<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Wirz">{{cite web|url=http://www.wirz.de/music/burnsfrm.htm |title=Eddie Burns & Jimmy Burns Discography |publisher=Wirz.de |accessdate=2012-12-16}}</ref>

==Quotation==
{{cquote|Many music lovers don't know that nearly a whole generation of original and highly talented musicians in Detroit were either snuffed out or forced to flee Detroit to keep their music careers alive. You'd come into the studio, cut a record, and they'd pay you maybe $20 and a bottle of whiskey. It didn't matter if the record sold ten copies or if they sold ten thousand.}}
''[[Fifth Estate (periodical)|Fifth Estate]]'' - September 1973<ref>{{cite book
| first= Dan
| last= Georgakas
| year= 1998
| title= Detroit, I Do Mind Dying: A Study in Urban Revolution
| edition= 1st
| publisher= South End Press 
| location= Cambridge, Massachusetts
| page= 107
| isbn= 0-89608-571-6}}</ref>
